All Rights Reserved.</rights><atom10:link xmlns:atom10="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" rel="self" type="application/atom+xml" href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/AtlanticNational" /><feedburner:info uri="atlanticnational" /><atom10:link xmlns:atom10="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" rel="hub" href="http://pubsubhubbub.appspot.com/" /><entry><content type="html"><p>I <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/orbital-view-city-of-roses/481215/?utm_source=feed">recently wrote about</a> my hometown, Portland, Oregon. Here’s a shot of my other home, New York City:</p><blockquote class="instagram-media" data-instgrm-version="7" style=" background:#FFF; border:0; border-radius:3px; box-shadow:0 0 1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.5),0 1px 10px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.15); margin: 1px; max-width:658px; padding:0; width:99.375%; width:-webkit-calc(100% - 2px); width:calc(100% - 2px);">
<div style="padding:8px;">
<div style=" background:#F8F8F8; line-height:0; margin-top:40px; padding:50.0% 0; text-align:center; width:100%;">
<div style=" background:url(data:image/png;base64,); display:block; height:44px; margin:0 auto -44px; position:relative; top:-22px; width:44px;"></div>
</div>

<p style=" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px; margin-bottom:0; margin-top:8px; overflow:hidden; padding:8px 0 7px; text-align:center; text-overflow:ellipsis; white-space:nowrap;"><a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/BFRfnBzM2Fd/" style=" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; font-style:normal; font-weight:normal; line-height:17px; text-decoration:none;" target="_blank">A photo posted by Tim Peake (@astro_timpeake)</a> on <time datetime="2016-05-11T16:16:31+00:00" style=" font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px;">May 11, 2016 at 9:16am PDT</time></p>
</div>
</blockquote><script async defer src="//platform.instagram.com/en_US/embeds.js"></script><p>“These little town blues,” as astronaut Tim Peake puns in his caption, describe the smallness of the city from space as well as referencing <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=btFfXgUdIzY">Frank Sinatra’s classic</a>. As Peake notes, the left side of this photo is north, and Manhattan is the island in the middle. That big green rectangle is Central Park, of course, but the city’s iconic buildings are hardly visible. At this distance, the city of 8.4 million people looks to me like nothing so much as the lichens I found growing on rocks and tree bark while hiking with my family back in the Pacific Northwest—a very different environment from the paved and polished city I now know.</p><p>And yet, for a city like New York, lichens are a fitting metaphor. They’re composite organisms, as <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lichen">Wikipedia explains</a>:</p><blockquote>
<p>A lichen … arises from algae or <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cyanobacteria" title="Cyanobacteria">cyanobacteria</a> (or both) living among filaments of a fungus in a symbiotic relationship. The combined life form has properties that are very different from the properties of its component organisms. … Lichens are abundant growing on bark, leaves, mosses, on other lichens, and hanging from branches “living on thin air” ... They grow on bare rock, walls, gravestones, roofs, exposed soil surfaces, and in the soil as part of a <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_soil_crust" title="Biological soil crust">biological soil crust</a>. Different kinds of lichens have adapted to survive in some of the most extreme environments on Earth. … They are relatively self-contained miniature ecosystems in and of themselves.</p>
</blockquote><p>That’s New York to me: an ecosystem made up of overlapping life forms, something greater than the sum of its parts and its people. It’s the harshest place I’ve ever been, and also the most fertile. When I came to New York for college, like so many people before me, I was thrilled by the city’s crowds and constant activity, and also overwhelmed by them. I felt small, anonymous, insignificant, invisible. And I felt alive, swept up in the bloodstream of something greater than myself.</p><p>Maybe lichens are the consummate New Yorkers—unassuming, abundant, tenacious. Above all, they survive, and they transform themselves and each other. They are, as poet Jane Hirshfield writes in our <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2011/04/for-the-lichens/308411/?utm_source=feed">April 2011 issue</a>:</p><blockquote>
<p>chemists of air,<br>
changers of nitrogen-unusable into nitrogen-usable. …</p>

<p>Transformers unvalued, uncounted.<br>
Cell by cell, word by word, making a world they could live in.</p>
</blockquote><p dir="ltr"><em>(See all Orbital Views <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/category/orbital-view/?utm_source=feed">here</a>)</em></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/TtZf2ENJ3RE" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Rosa Inocencio Smith</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/rosa-smith/</uri></author><title type="html">Orbital View: A Great Place to Feel Small</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/TtZf2ENJ3RE/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-12T17:00:00-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-12T17:01:32-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:374-482568</id><summary type="html">I <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/orbital-view-city-of-roses/481215/">recently wrote about</a> my hometown, Portland, Oregon. Here&#x2019;s a shot of my other home, New York City: …</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/orbital-view-a-good-place-to-feel-small/482568/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p><strong>Trump and Ryan meeting, cont’d</strong>: The two men released a joint statement on their meeting this morning.</p><blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en">
<p dir="ltr" lang="en">just in: joint statement from Paul Ryan and Donald Trump <a href="https://t.co/83oaxhcaEH">pic.twitter.com/83oaxhcaEH</a></p>
— Rosie Gray (@RosieGray) <a href="https://twitter.com/RosieGray/status/730775940993847296">May 12, 2016</a></blockquote><script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><p><strong>George Zimmerman’s gun auction, cont’d</strong>: <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/george-zimmerman-gun-auction/482460/?utm_source=feed">Here’s the latest</a> on this morning’s news:</p><blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-partner="tweetdeck">
<p dir="ltr" lang="en">Link at site selling <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/GeorgeZimmerman?src=hash">#GeorgeZimmerman</a> 's gun now has error message.<a href="https://t.co/84mVKJcpVC">https://t.co/84mVKJcpVC</a> cc <a href="https://twitter.com/TheAtlantic">@TheAtlantic</a> <a href="https://t.co/D8T9ZRpd2i">pic.twitter.com/D8T9ZRpd2i</a></p>
— What Matters Now (@TheAtlNews) <a href="https://twitter.com/TheAtlNews/status/730782785082920960">May 12, 2016</a></blockquote><script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><p><strong>Kenya declared non-compliant with sports anti-doping rules</strong>: The move means Kenyan athletes could miss the 2016 Rio Olympics.</p><blockquote class="twitter-tweet" data-lang="en">
<p dir="ltr" lang="en">The <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/WADA?src=hash">#WADA</a> CRC has made the unanimous recommendation that <a href="https://twitter.com/hashtag/Kenya?src=hash">#Kenya</a> be declared non-compliant with immediate effect.</p>
— WADA (@wada_ama) <a href="https://twitter.com/wada_ama/status/730791681503731712">May 12, 2016</a></blockquote><script async src="//platform.twitter.com/widgets.js" charset="utf-8"></script><p><strong>News from the morning</strong> <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/what-were-following-this-morning/482457/?utm_source=feed">here</a></p><p></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/LQW8WpfQcIY" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Krishnadev Calamur</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/krishnadev-calamur/</uri></author><title type="html">What We're Following This Afternoon</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/LQW8WpfQcIY/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-12T13:14:35-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-12T13:14:36-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:374-482547</id><summary type="html"><strong>Trump and Ryan meeting, cont&#x2019;d</strong>: The two men released a joint statement on their meeting this morning. …</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/what-were-following-this-afternoon/482547/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p>Now that our aerial feature has grown to <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/america-by-air-suburban-sunset/481521/?utm_source=feed">include videos</a>, I figured I’d throw a new medium in the mix: I snagged this (<s>cinemagraph</s>? <s>Boomerang</s>?) short video back in 2015:</p><center><script type="text/javascript" class="phhhoto-embed" data-phhhoto="fQpMR3b4au0" src="//embed.phhhoto.com/embed.js"></script></center><p>That bright part on the righthand side? That’s Downtown Los Angeles. Here’s another grab from the same flight, as the plane neared landing at LAX:</p><center>
<p><script type="text/javascript" class="phhhoto-embed" data-phhhoto="Wj1KDOb4au1" src="//embed.phhhoto.com/embed.js"></script></p>
</center><p>This flight path never gets old, and the sheer amount of L.A. sprawl astonishes me. I love how there are speckles of light in every direction, like endless constellations in the night sky. (Of course, the actual constellations are blocked by the city’s smog.) As the band Thirty Seconds To Mars put it in their 2013 song, Los Angeles is truly “<a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xtk8ro_eJZE">the land of a billion lights</a>.”</p><p><em>(America by Air archive <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/category/america-by-air/?utm_source=feed">here</a>. Submission guidelines <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/all/2016/02/your-views-of-america-from-the-air/462432/?utm_source=feed#note-462156">here</a>.)</em></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/ejgNJt7tqs4" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Caroline Mimbs Nyce</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/caroline-mimbs-nyce/</uri></author><title type="html">America by Air: 'The Land of a Billion Lights'</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/ejgNJt7tqs4/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-12T12:15:00-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-12T12:47:39-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:374-482409</id><summary type="html">Now that our aerial feature has grown to <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/america-by-air-suburban-sunset/481521/">include videos</a>, I figured I&#x2019;d throw a new medium in the mix…</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/america-by-air-the-land-of-a-billion-lights/482409/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p>The U.S. Marine Corps has allowed two female service members to join the infantry, marking the first time women will hold jobs in the combat force.</p><p>The Marines have approved one woman to become a rifleman and another to become a machine gunner, <em>The Military Times</em> <a href="http://www.militarytimes.com/story/military/2016/05/09/female-marine-rifleman-machine-gunner-headed-infantry/84156638/">reported</a> Monday. Both women requested the jobs.</p><p>“The Corps applauds the time and efforts of those Marines who volunteered,” said Captain Philip Kulczewski, a Marine spokesman at the Pentagon. More from <em>The Military Times:</em></p><blockquote>
<p>Since no women have graduated from the service’s Infantry Officer Course, female Marine or Navy officers assigned to infantry battalions will serve in support roles. The 30th female Marine to attempt IOC left her class on April 21 after she was unable to complete two hikes. She has the opportunity to attempt the course again in July.</p>
</blockquote><p>The Marines did not release the women’s names. Under the service’s gender-integration policy, two female officers will be assigned to the infantry unit 90 days before its new members arrive.              </p><p>The U.S. military <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2015/12/women-in-the-military/418680/?utm_source=feed">announced</a> in December it would open all combat jobs in every branch of the armed forces to women starting this year. “They’ll be able to serve as Army Rangers and Green Berets, Navy SEALs, Marine Corps infantry, Air Force parajumpers, and everything else that was previously open only to men,” U.S. Defense Secretary Ash Carter said at the time.</p><p>Carter <a href="http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/story/military/2016/04/15/first-female-marine-applies-join-infantry/83073068/">approved</a> the Marine Corps’ gender integration plan in March, making 233 women who graduated from infantry training and other military occupational-specialty schools eligible to apply for combat jobs.</p><p>The U.S. military will see several firsts for female service members this year. The Army <a href="http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/world/2016/04/15/army-women-new-rules-infantry-armor-officers/83036812/">announced</a> last month that 22 women would be commissioned as infantry and armor officers for the first time. A female staff sergeant will <a href="http://www.marinecorpstimes.com/story/military/2016/03/28/female-admin-marine-attempt-marsoc-training-summer/82347390/">attempt</a> the six-week course of the Marine Corps’s special-operations command this summer; if she completes training, she could become the first female critical-skills operator. The Navy has begun collecting applications for SEAL training from men and women, but <a href="http://www.navytimes.com/story/military/2016/04/19/navy-seals-now-open-women-but-none-has-stepped-forward/82982558/">no women have applied</a> as of this month.</p><hr><h3>Related Video</h3><p></p><figure><iframe allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen" frameborder="0" height="360" mozallowfullscreen="mozallowfullscreen" src="http://www.theatlantic.com/video/iframe/423600/" webkitallowfullscreen="webkitallowfullscreen" width="640"></iframe>

<figcaption class="caption">Long before the Pentagon's announcement, women were already embedded in the front lines of Afghanistan.</figcaption></figure><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/AKFVZ3LPpUo" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Marina Koren</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/marina-koren/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2016/05/RTX1QNYA/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Mario Anzuoni / Reuters</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">The First Infantry Women of the U.S. Marines </title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/AKFVZ3LPpUo/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-12T11:43:53-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-12T14:06:36-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:50-482520</id><summary type="html">The Corps has approved two women for roles previously open only to men.</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/women-marines-combat/482520/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p><small><em>Updated on May 12 at 6:24 p.m. ET</em></small></p><p>The gun George Zimmerman used to kill Trayvon Martin and which he had hoped to sell Thursday now appears to be back on sale at another website—after it was pulled from the site where it was originally being auctioned.</p><p>The 9 mm Kel-Tec PF-9 pistol was initially listed for sale at <a href="http://www.gunbroker.com/Auction/ViewItem.aspx?Item=558112068">Gunbroker.com</a>, but the site later pulled the listing, <a href="http://www.gunbroker.com/User/Announce.aspx">saying</a>:</p><blockquote>
<p>Listings on the GunBroker.com web site are user-generated, exactly like social media posts. Mr. Zimmerman never contacted anyone at GunBroker.com prior to or after the listing was created and no one at GunBroker.com has any relationship with Zimmerman. Our <a href="http://www.gunbroker.com/User/SiteRules.aspx" target="_Blank">site rules</a> state that we reserve the right to reject listings at our sole discretion, and have done so with the Zimmerman listing.</p>

<p>We want no part in the listing on our web site or in any of the publicity it is receiving.</p>

<p></p>
</blockquote><p>The site now listing it is United Gun Group, <a href="http://www.unitedgungroup.com/auction/detail/auction/9/slug/george-zimmerman-s-gun-used-2-26-12">but that website appears to be down</a>. <a href="https://www.facebook.com/Unitedgungroup/?pnref=lhc">In a statement on Facebook</a>, that website said:</p><blockquote>
<p>United Gun Group offers a free platform for law-abiding citizens to buy, sell, trade and discuss firearms and related products. United Gun Group’s stance is that as long as Mr. Zimmerman (or any other UGG member) is obeying the letter of the law, his personal firearm sale will be permitted on our network. … He appears to be following all applicable laws.</p>

<p></p>
</blockquote><p>Zimmerman, the neighborhood-watch volunteer, was acquitted of murder in the 2012 shooting death of Martin, a black 17-year-old, in Sanford, Florida. Here’s an excerpt from the Gunbroker.com posting when it was still online:</p><blockquote>
<p>Prospective bidders, I am honored and humbled to announce the sale of an American Firearm Icon. The firearm for sale is the firearm that was used to defend my life and end the brutal attack from Trayvon Martin on 2/26/2012. … Many have expressed interest in owning and displaying the firearm including The Smithsonian Museum in Washington D.C. This is a piece of American History.</p>
</blockquote><p>The gun, Zimmerman says, was recently returned to him by the U.S. Department of Justice. He said he hopes to get at least $5,000 for the weapon, and a portion of the proceeds “<span>will be used to: fight BLM violence against Law Enforcement officers, ensure the demise of” Angela Corey’s career as a prosecutor, “and Hillary Clinton’s anti-firearm rhetoric.” His posting ends with the words “</span>Si Vis Pacem Para Bellum,” a Latin phrase that means “if you want peace, prepare for war.”</p><p>BLM refers to the Black Lives Matter movement, which sprung up following several high-profile incidents in which white police officers killed unarmed black men. Corey is the Florida State Attorney who failed in her attempt to prosecute Zimmerman for killing Martin. She is up for re-election.</p><p>The Smithsonian, <a href="http://newsdesk.si.edu/releases/statement-smithsonian-george-zimmerman-s-firearm">in a statement</a>, denied it had expressed interest in the weapon.</p><blockquote>
<p>The Smithsonian has never expressed interest in collecting George Zimmerman’s firearm. The Smithsonian has no plans to ever collect or display this object in any of its museums.</p>
</blockquote><p>The planned auction of the weapon prompted criticism Thursday. Indeed, Zimmerman <a href="http://www.fox35orlando.com/news/local-news/140127772-story">told WOFL-TV</a> in Orlando, Florida, he’d received several death threats after putting the gun up for sale. “What I've decided to do is not cower,” he said. I’m “a free American. I can do what I want with my possessions.”</p><p>Martin was walking to his father’s home in 2012 when he was shot and killed by Zimmerman inside a gated community. The neighborhood-watch volunteer said he felt threatened by the 17-year-old and successfully argued in court that his actions were protected by Florida’s Stand Your Ground laws.</p><p>Since that time, Zimmerman has been charged with assault following complaints from two girlfriends, who subsequently declined to cooperate with police, leading to the charges being dropped.</p><p>The auction for his weapon was set to begin at 11 a.m. EDT Thursday and end 24 hours later.</p><p>Reacting to the planned sale, Daryl Parks, an attorney for Martin’s family, <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2016/05/12/trayvon-martin-family-attorney-george-zimmerman-gun-auction-insulting-and-disrespectful/?tid=sm_tw">told <em>The Washington Post</em></a>: “It is insulting to this family that he would decided that he would sell the gun that he killed their child with. Think about what that means: This is a gun that took a child’s life and now he wants to make money off of it.”</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/WHTVrx6tLaA" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Krishnadev Calamur</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/krishnadev-calamur/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2016/05/AP_664658564715/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Joe Burbank / Orlando Sentinel / AP</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">George Zimmerman's Designs to Profit From Trayvon Martin's Death</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/WHTVrx6tLaA/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-12T08:36:18-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-12T18:33:17-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:50-482460</id><summary type="html">The pistol he used to kill the 17-year-old is now on sale at another website after it was pulled from sale at another auction site.</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/george-zimmerman-gun-auction/482460/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p><strong>Trump to meet Ryan</strong>: It would be their first meeting since Donald Trump became the presumptive GOP nominee. Paul Ryan, the House speaker, has said he’s not yet ready to support his fellow Republican.</p><p><strong>Brazil politics, cont’d</strong>: Senators voted 55-22 to suspend President Dilma Rousseff. Vice President Michael Temer assumes the presidency while Rousseff’s impeachment trial goes ahead. <strong>Update</strong>: <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/05/brazil-impeachment-dilma-rousseff/482427/?utm_source=feed">More here</a></p><p><strong>George Zimmerman to auction gun</strong>: He’s <a href="http://www.fox35orlando.com/news/local-news/140127772-story">hoping to get</a> at least $5,000 for the weapon used to kill Trayvon Martin. <strong>Update</strong>: <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/george-zimmerman-gun-auction/482460/?utm_source=feed">More here</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/UiYD18RlhTY" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Krishnadev Calamur</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/krishnadev-calamur/</uri></author><title type="html">What We're Following This Morning</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/UiYD18RlhTY/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-12T06:00:00-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-12T08:40:44-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:374-482457</id><summary type="html"><strong>Trump to meet Ryan</strong>: It would be their first meeting since Donald Trump became the presumptive GOP nominee. Paul Ryan…</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/what-were-following-this-morning/482457/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p>“The boys’ penguins were fatter and wearing sunglasses, and the girls’ penguins were skinnier with eyelashes, rosy cheeks, and lips. I was like, ‘Man, those are <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2016/05/pink-is-for-boys-too/481659/?utm_source=feed">penguins</a>! This is messed up!’”<cite> —<strong>Courtney Hartman</strong>, who designs kids’ clothes, on shopping for penguin pajamas.</cite></p><p>“When results of huge studies like this one appear, some people head straight for Tigger’s camp and others for Eeyore’s. I find myself <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/science/archive/2016/05/the-genetics-of-staying-in-school/482052/?utm_source=feed">somewhere in between</a>,” <cite>—<strong>Kathryn Ashbury</strong>, who studies education and genetics.</cite></p><p>“Can we <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2016/05/a-better-way-to-read/482127/?utm_source=feed">multitask</a>? The research, more and more, shows that we all suck at it,” <cite>—<strong>Randolph Bias</strong>, who studies reading comprehension.</cite></p><p><em>(Previous quotes from our sources <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/category/quoted/?utm_source=feed">here</a>)</em></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/gqDpsrWVWBs" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Rosa Inocencio Smith</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/rosa-smith/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/notes/2016/05/RTR2MX9T/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Suzanne Plunkett / Reuters</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">Quoted</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/gqDpsrWVWBs/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-11T19:00:00-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-11T19:00:27-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:374-482433</id><summary type="html">&#x201C;The boys&#x2019; penguins were fatter and wearing sunglasses, and the girls&#x2019; penguins were skinnier with eyelashes, rosy cheeks, and lips…</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/quoted-on-051116/482433/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p dir="ltr">The man who allegedly killed three people and injured nine others<strong> </strong>last year at a Planned Parenthood facility in Colorado Springs is not fit to stand trial, a Colorado judge <a href="http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_29878482/planned-parenthood-shooters-competency-be-decided-wednesday">ruled Wednesday</a>.</p><p dir="ltr">Robert Dear, <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/04/planned-parenthood-shooter/477825/?utm_source=feed">who said</a> that he would be greeted at the gates of heaven by aborted fetuses, has admitted to the deadly, six-hour standoff with police last November. Dear used four Soviet-style SKS semi-automatic rifles, a shotgun, a rifle, and two handguns in the shooting. Dear said he attacked the Planned Parenthood in an attempt to prevent women from obtaining abortions.</p><p dir="ltr">Judge Gilbert Martinez ordered Dear to be sent to the Colorado Mental Health Institute in Pueblo. A doctor had previously testified that Dear suffered from delusions. <a href="http://www.kktv.com/content/news/Accused-Planned-Parenthood-shooters-mental-competency-up-for-debate-378888511.html">Local CBS affiliate KKTV reports</a>:</p><blockquote>
<p dir="ltr">Surveillance video of Dear drinking out of his toilet was shown in court. [The doctor] says that could be linked to his suspicion that he is being poisoned, which Dear loudly concurred with during the testimony. The doctor concluded that Dear's rational understanding of the case is interwoven with his delusion that the FBI is after him. Dear made several outbursts in court, including a rant about the bad things that happened to people who “made fun of Obama.”</p>
</blockquote><p dir="ltr">Wednesday’s ruling delays the case against Dear, who has been charged with 179 criminal counts, including murder and attempted murder, until he is found competent to stand trial. Martinez said he would issue a written review of the case on August 11.</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/AiE_twB3qrk" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Matt Vasilogambros</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/matt-vasilogambros/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2016/05/RTX1XZWV/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Andy Cross / Reuters</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">Colorado Planned Parenthood Shooter Ruled Not Fit for Trial</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/AiE_twB3qrk/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-11T16:13:43-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-11T16:13:43-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:50-482391</id><summary type="html">A judge has ordered Robert Dear, who is accused of killing three people in November, to be sent a psychiatric institute.</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/planned-parenthood-shooter-not-fit-for-trial/482391/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p dir="ltr">The April 2013 fire that engulfed a fertilizer plant in West, Texas, and killed 15 people was set on purpose, federal investigators <a href="https://twitter.com/ATFHQ/status/730447106620690432">announced</a> Wednesday.</p><p>“This fire was a criminal act,” Robert Elder, the special agent in charge of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF), said at a news conference.</p><p>ATF, which led the investigation, did not say if murder charges connected to the fire would be filed. Investigators interviewed 400 people and spent $2 million on the investigation, <a href="https://twitter.com/ATFHQ/status/730447460812894208">ATF officials said</a>. Twelve of the 15 people who were killed were emergency responders. Another 200 people were wounded in the blast.</p><p dir="ltr"><a href="http://www.cnn.com/2016/05/11/us/texas-fertilizer-plant-blast/index.html">According to CNN</a>:</p><blockquote>
<p dir="ltr">That night, a fire broke out at the West Fertilizer Co. in the town of West, about 70 miles south of Dallas. Twenty minutes later, the plant exploded with such force it caused a magnitude-2.1 earthquake. “It was like a nuclear bomb went off,” West Mayor Tommy Muska said.</p>
</blockquote><p dir="ltr">After the explosion, investigators from the U.S. Chemical Safety Board said the explosion was preventable, adding the plant’s 270 tons of ammonium nitrate that exploded from the fire was a serious hazard. The explosion was a national tragedy, prompting a visit from President Obama for a memorial service in nearby Waco, Texas.</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/DvJqRGZ1ANo" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Matt Vasilogambros</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/matt-vasilogambros/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2016/05/RTXYQ9M/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Mike Stone / Reuters</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">West, Texas, Explosion Was a 'Criminal Act'</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/DvJqRGZ1ANo/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-11T13:51:45-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-11T13:51:54-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:50-482343</id><summary type="html">Federal investigators said the fertilizer-plant fire in 2013 that killed 15 people was deliberately set.</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/west-texas-explosion/482343/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p dir="ltr"><em><small>Updated on May 11 at 3:05 p.m. ET</small></em></p><p dir="ltr">A federal grand jury this week indicted the former North Charleston, South Carolina, police officer who shot Walter Scott, the unarmed black man, in the back last April.</p><p dir="ltr">Michael Slager was charged with three crimes, including depriving Scott, the 50-year-old who was killed, of his civil rights. Slager, who was fired following the incident, shot Scott after a traffic stop.</p><p dir="ltr"><em><a href="http://www.postandcourier.com/20160511/160519884/michael-slager-charged-with-federal-civil-rights-violation-obstruction-in-walter-scott-shooting">The Post and Courier</a></em> describes the federal charges:</p><blockquote>
<p dir="ltr">The indictment alleges that Slager was acting with his authority as a policeman when he used unreasonable force — a violation of the Constitution—by shooting Scott five times from behind. He also was indicted on counts of using a firearm in a violent crime and obstruction of justice after he told state investigators that Scott was coming at him with his own Taser when he fired. A video showed Scott running away.</p>
</blockquote><p dir="ltr">The indictment did not include race as a factor in the shooting despite the Black Lives Matter movement protesting the killing of the black man by the white officer. Slager <a href="http://bigstory.ap.org/article/15a9b91a18604b61882267eee16e2439/white-ex-cop-faces-federal-charges-black-motorists-death">will remain</a> free on bail.</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/aLbXFRBxLRo" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Matt Vasilogambros</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/matt-vasilogambros/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2016/05/RTX2DTYQ/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Randall Hill / Reuters</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">An Indictment in the Walter Scott Shooting</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/aLbXFRBxLRo/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-11T11:23:23-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-11T15:05:01-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:50-482280</id><summary type="html">Michael Slager, the officer who shot the unarmed man five times in the back, was charged with three federal counts this week.</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/walter-scott-shooting-officer-indicted/482280/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p>The U.S. Military Academy at West Point will not punish 16 graduating African-American female cadets seen in a photograph with their fists raised—an action that prompted speculation they were celebrating the Black Lives Matter movement. But the officer who investigated the photograph after interviewing the women and others said he did find their actions “inappropriate.”</p><p>Here’s a statement from <a href="http://www.westpoint.edu/news/Shared%20Documents/WEST%20POINT%20PHOTO%20INQUIRY%20CLEARS%20CADETS.pdf">West Point</a>:</p><blockquote>
<p>The inquiry concluded that the photo was among several taken in the spur-of-the-moment. It was intended to demonstrate “unity” and “pride,” according to the findings of the inquiry.</p>

<p>In addition to concluding there was no violation of DOD Directive 1344.10, the findings state, “that based upon available evidence none of the participants, through their actions, intended to show support for a political movement.”</p>

<p></p>
</blockquote><p>Controversy over the photograph, taken on April 26, erupted after it was <a href="http://www.armytimes.com/story/military/2016/05/10/west-point-cadet-photo-inappropriate-but-not-political/84196326/">published in the <em>Army Times</em></a>. Many commenters speculated the women were celebrating the Black Lives Matter movement; others said it was black-power salute akin to the ones raised by John Carlos and Tommie Smith at the 1968 Mexico City Olympics. While some of those commenters were sympathetic to the women in the photograph, others pointed out that it violated military code, specifically a regulation governing m<span style="line-height: 1.66667;">embers of the armed forces engaging in permissible political activities. They shall, <a href="http://www.dtic.mil/whs/directives/corres/pdf/134410p.pdf">the rule says</a>, “Refrain from participating in any political activity while in military uniform, as proscribed by Reference (c), or using Government facilities or resources for furthering political activities.”</span> The women themselves have not themselves commented on the photograph.</p><p>The officer who investigated the photograph wrote in the report:</p><blockquote>
<p>Based on the fact that the photo has caused a perception of impropriety on the part of the sixteen female Cadets, I recommend all photographed individuals receive a block of instruction designed and implemented by the Simon Center for Professional Military Excellence, intended to educate the Cadets on the impact of their actions. I recommend this instruction be completed prior to the May graduation of the USMA Class of 2016. I do not feel the graduation of any of the sixteen Cadets in the photograph should be delayed, so long as they display an understanding of how their actions as Cadets and future Officers were inappropriate, at the conclusion of the instruction.</p>
</blockquote><p>You can read the inquiry <a href="http://www.westpoint.edu/news/Shared%20Documents/Preliminary%20Inquiry%20%20REDACTED.pdf">here</a>.</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/DWosMGO8jVc" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Krishnadev Calamur</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/krishnadev-calamur/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2016/05/westpoint/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Mike Segar / Reuters</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">The Controversy Over a Photograph At West Point</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/DWosMGO8jVc/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-11T10:06:19-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-11T17:33:21-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:50-482250</id><summary type="html">The U.S. Military Academy said it won&rsquo;t punish the cadets seen in the photograph with their fists raised.</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/west-point-cadets-photograph/482250/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><figure><img alt="" height="417" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/ewert_miami_101/2fb924a30.jpg" width="630"><figcaption class="credit"><a href="http://www.ewertphotography.com/">Edward L. Ewert</a></figcaption></figure><p>A pristine view of the city’s waterfront comes from reader Edward:</p><blockquote>
<p>I started taking airplane photos in earnest about five years ago when it dawned on me that people, including myself, were numb to the wonders of flying. It has become a rather unpleasant ordeal in the last 15 years or so, but the wonders that speed by still amaze.</p>

<figure class="right"><img alt="" height="160" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/infrared/9ec0bb336.jpg" width="227"></figure><p>I shoot most of my window seat photos with an infrared modified camera, which helps cut through the inevitable haze at 30K+ feet. It gives a unique look, and I’ve included one sample to give you an idea (on approach to LAX). The other is a more conventional color photo over Miami, Florida.</p>
</blockquote><p dir="ltr">But how colorful it is! <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/all/2016/02/your-views-of-america-from-the-air/462432/?utm_source=feed#note-471693">Here’s a less scenic</a> but still really cool shot of Miami from another mid-flight reader. Send your own, as always, to <a href="mailto:hello@theatlantic.com">hello@</a>.</p><p dir="ltr"><em>(America by Air archive <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/category/america-by-air/?utm_source=feed">here</a>. Submission guidelines <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/all/2016/02/your-views-of-america-from-the-air/462432/?utm_source=feed#note-462156">here</a>.)</em></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/Zm-jodV1Ya8" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Chris Bodenner</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/chris-bodenner/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/notes/2016/05/ewert_miami_101/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Edward L. Ewert</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">America by Air: Miami in Aquamarine</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/Zm-jodV1Ya8/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-11T09:15:00-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-11T10:53:40-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:374-482256</id><summary type="html">A pristine view of the city&#x2019;s waterfront comes from reader Edward: I started taking airplane photos in…</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/america-by-air-aquamarine-over-miami/482256/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p><small><em>Updated on May 11 at 12:24 p.m. ET</em></small></p><p>Dozens of people are dead Wednesday in a car-bomb explosion in Baghdad’s predominantly Shia Sadr City neighborhood. The death toll in the attack claimed by ISIS has climbed to <a href="http://www.reuters.com/article/us-mideast-crisis-iraq-blast-idUSKCN0Y20MV">at least 80</a>, making it the deadliest attack on the Iraqi capital in 2016.</p><p><a href="http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/M/ML_IRAQ?SITE=AP&amp;SECTION=HOME&amp;TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&amp;CTIME=2016-05-11-06-43-07">The AP has more</a>:</p><blockquote>
<p>Ambulances rushed to the scene where dozens of residents walked through the twisted and mangled wreckage of cars and other debris that littered the pavement, trying to help the victims. The street was stained red with blood in many places and front-side facades of several buildings were heavily damaged. Smoke billowed from ground-level stores gutted out by the explosion.</p>
</blockquote><p>Separately, two other blasts in northern Baghdad killed 18 people.</p><p>Iraqi and Kurdish forces, backed by the U.S. and its allies, have pushed back ISIS, which controls large parts of Iraq and neighboring Syria. But the group shows the ability to strike targets inside Iraq, and farther afield, with apparent ease.</p><p>Overall, <a href="http://www.uniraq.org/index.php?option=com_k2&amp;view=item&amp;id=5580:un-casualty-figures-for-iraq-for-the-month-of-april-2016&amp;Itemid=633&amp;lang=en">the UN says</a> 1,885 civilians were killed in Iraq in the first four months of 2016.</p><p></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/qc-YDZGFCeI" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Krishnadev Calamur</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/krishnadev-calamur/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2016/05/AP_16132347456608/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Khalid Mohammed / AP</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">The Latest Baghdad Bombing</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/qc-YDZGFCeI/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-11T07:27:48-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-11T12:26:56-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:50-482244</id><summary type="html">Dozens were killed in the attack claimed by ISIS on a Shiite neighborhood.</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/iraq-car-bomb/482244/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p><strong>Sanders wins in West Virginia</strong>: The Democratic presidential candidate <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/05/live-coverage-of-the-west-virginia-and-nebraska-primaries/482037/?utm_source=feed">defeated Hillary Clinton</a>, who has all but secured her party’s nomination. In the Republican races, Donald Trump, the party’s presumptive nominee, triumphed in West Virginia and Nebraska.</p><p><strong>Car bomb hits Baghdad market</strong>: ISIS claimed responsibility for the attack on the Shia neighborhood of Sadr City. The blast killed at least 29 people, Iraqi officials said. <strong>Update</strong>: <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/iraq-car-bomb/482244/?utm_source=feed">More here</a></p><p><strong>Queen Elizabeth II called Chinese officials “rude”</strong>: Tuesday’s exchange with Lucy D’Orsi, the Metropolitan Police Commander, <a href="http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-36263685">was caught on film</a>. She was describing the Chinese treatment of Britain’s ambassador to Beijing. <strong>Update</strong>: <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/05/britain-china-queen/482247/?utm_source=feed">More here</a></p><p></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/dWE1-uso0jY" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Krishnadev Calamur</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/krishnadev-calamur/</uri></author><title type="html">What We're Following This Morning </title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/dWE1-uso0jY/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-11T06:00:00-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-11T08:50:25-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:374-482241</id><summary type="html"><strong>Sanders wins in West Virginia</strong>: The Democratic presidential candidate <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/05/live-coverage-of-the-west-virginia-and-nebraska-primaries/482037/">defeated Hillary Clinton</a>, who has all but secured her party&#x2019;s nomination…</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/what-were-following-this-morning/482241/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p>Two California sheriff’s deputies were charged Tuesday in connection with the beating of a suspected car thief in San Francisco, almost six months after surveillance-camera footage of the incident was released to the public.</p><p>The San Francisco public defender’s office<strong> </strong>received the alleyway surveillance footage from an anonymous sender and posted it on YouTube in November. In the video, two deputies with the Alameda County Sheriff’s Office can be seen chasing a suspected car thief––later identified as Stanislav Petrov––into an alley in the Mission District, tackle him, then kick and beat him with batons until other officers arrive.</p><p>The two deputies, Paul Wieber and Luis Santamaria, have been charged each with multiple felonies, including assault with a deadly weapon, battery, and assault under color of authority.</p><p>The <em>San Francisco Chronicle</em> <a href="http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/SF-prosecutors-to-announce-charging-decision-in-7442018.php">reported</a> that the video:</p><blockquote>
<p>… captured the deputies swinging on Petrov “over the course of 40 seconds, striking him at least 30 times,” prosecutors wrote. “During the beating, Mr. Petrov is heard crying out and saying, ‘I’m sorry,’ ‘Help me,’ and ‘Oh my God.’ The deputies stopped striking Mr. Petrov when other peace officers from multiple law enforcement agencies arrived.”</p>

<p><span style="line-height: 1.66667;">Petrov suffered a concussion with a mild brain injury, deep head cuts and multiple broken bones in both hands, authorities said. Surgeons had to insert plates, screws and pins into his hands to repair them.</span></p>
</blockquote><p>Petrov’s attorneys have filed a complaint against Alameda County that alleges deputies took “trophy photos” with Petrov’s bleeding body after the beating, and that the two deputies were allowed to <a href="http://www.sfgate.com/crime/article/Deputies-revised-reports-in-alley-beating-7218758.php">change their original reports</a> after the surveillance video surfaced. Those altered reports were only made public after they were requested by the Center for Human Rights and Privacy, a civil-rights group.</p><p>San Francisco District Attorney George Gascón said Tuesday that<strong> </strong>an investigation into the incident would continue. He said there were still “allegations related to false police statements, theft, bribery, witness tampering, and/or other wrongdoing related to this case.” He did not explain the time lapse between the release of the video and the announcement of charges.</p><p>In March, the <em>Chronicle </em><a href="http://www.sfgate.com/crime/article/Enhanced-video-shows-deputy-taking-suspect-s-7380140.php">reported that</a><strong> </strong>a third deputy seen in the video allegedly stole money and jewelry from Petrov, then gave it to a homeless couple who had witnessed the beating.</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/gzDkDjeUxEw" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>J. Weston Phippen</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/j-weston-phippen/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2016/05/AP_299512941764_1/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Eric Risberg / AP</media:credit><media:description>San Francisco District Attorney George Gascon</media:description></media:content><title type="html">The Charges Against Two California Deputies</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/gzDkDjeUxEw/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-10T19:01:00-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-10T19:02:03-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:50-482181</id><summary type="html">Two deputies have been charged with multiple felonies in connection with beating a suspected car thief in San Francisco.</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/san-francisco-deputies-charged/482181/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p>“If we don’t take care of the adults who are caring for children, their children will be negatively affected later—if not <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2016/05/social-workers-military-hospitals/480408/?utm_source=feed">immediately</a>,” <cite>—<strong>Allison Scobie-Carroll</strong>, a social worker.</cite></p><p>“These people just want more <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/05/court-packing-enjoys-a-political-renaissance/481758/?utm_source=feed">control</a>,” <cite>—<strong>Mark Harrison</strong>, a lawyer, on the plan to add more justices to Arizona’s Supreme Court.</cite></p><p>“Here I was this advocate for education, and I couldn’t find a place for my son. I was crying in the principal’s office and I said, ‘I don’t know what to do.’ The principal said, <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2016/05/detroits-school-crisis/482010/?utm_source=feed">‘I don’t either,’</a>” <cite>—<strong>Arlyssa Heard</strong>, a parent in Detroit.</cite></p><p><em>(Previous quotes from our sources <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/category/quoted/?utm_source=feed">here</a>)</em></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/K5ODR1vfCvE" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Rosa Inocencio Smith</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/rosa-smith/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/notes/2016/05/RTX2DFEV/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Damir In another, a 58-year-old man was shot in the head and killed at his dinner table by gunfire from outside on the Southwest Side.</p><p dir="ltr">The weekend was the most violent in the city since the end of September. There’s deeper concern that violence will continue to rise as the summer approaches. According to <a href="http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-chicago-weekend-shootings-violence-20160509-story.html">the <em>Chicago Tribune</em></a>:</p><blockquote>
<p dir="ltr">On April 20, Chicago reached 1,000 shooting victims for the year, six to nine weeks earlier than in the previous four years, according to data compiled by the <em>Tribune</em>. That grim milestone, for instance, wasn't reached until June 4 last year. Perhaps even more troubling, this marks the third consecutive year in which Chicago has seen double-digit increases in shootings.</p>
</blockquote><p dir="ltr">Chicago has recorded 200 homicides this year, and is on track for 500 homicides for the entire year. Police Superintendent Eddie Johnson called this weekend’s gun violence “completely unacceptable.”</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/67Yzu8F2O2w" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Matt Vasilogambros</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/matt-vasilogambros/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2016/05/RTX1JA3Y/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Jim Young / Reuters</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">A Violent Weekend in Chicago</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/67Yzu8F2O2w/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-10T11:42:54-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-10T11:42:54-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:50-482100</id><summary type="html">More than 50 people were shot and eight were killed over the weekend, putting the city on track to hit 500 homicides this year.</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/violent-weekend-in-chicago/482100/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><figure><img alt="" height="596" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/image1_6/9d9d18c8b.jpg" width="630"><figcaption class="credit">Alan Nelson</figcaption></figure><p>Stu Smith captured <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/all/2016/02/your-views-of-america-from-the-air/462432/?utm_source=feed#note-475101">one halo rainbow </a>for us a few months ago, but now Alan ups the ante:</p><blockquote>
<p>Here’s a photo for your consideration: a nice double rainbow during our departure out of Philadelphia the other day, with the Delaware River below. Always remember to look out the window …</p>
</blockquote><p dir="ltr">… or at least rewatch this classic YouTube:</p><p><iframe allowfullscreen="" frameborder="0" height="321" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/OQSNhk5ICTI" width="570"></iframe></p><p dir="ltr"><em>(America by Air archive <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/category/america-by-air/?utm_source=feed">here</a>. Submission guidelines <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/all/2016/02/your-views-of-america-from-the-air/462432/?utm_source=feed#note-462156">here</a>.)</em></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/nAY3PvzQFX4" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Chris Bodenner</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/chris-bodenner/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/notes/2016/05/image1_6/lead_960.jpg" /><title type="html">America by Air: Double Rainbow!</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/nAY3PvzQFX4/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-10T11:42:00-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-10T11:43:31-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:374-482103</id><summary type="html">Stu Smith captured <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/all/2016/02/your-views-of-america-from-the-air/462432/#note-475101">one halo rainbow </a>for us a few months ago, but now Alan ups the ante: …</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/america-by-air-double-rainbow/482103/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p>Governor Jerry Brown of California<strong> </strong>announced new changes to the state’s water-use policies Monday, extending some of the regulations the government had adopted to cope with the state’s ongoing, five-year drought and easing restrictions for those districts seeing more regular rainfall.  </p><p>The changes include a ban on hosing down driveways or washing cars with hoses that lack a shut-off nozzle, and watering lawns within two days of a rainstorm. They also include reduced restrictions regarding mandatory water rationing.</p><p>Two of California’s largest reservoirs have filled to 90 percent capacity, and this winter El Niño dropped plenty of snow in the mountains and helped the northern half of the state recover from years of record-low precipitation. But while some parts of California have returned to more regular rainfall, <a href="http://droughtmonitor.unl.edu/Home/StateDroughtMonitor.aspx?CA">90 percent of the state</a> remains in a drought. Recognizing those differences, the State Water Resources Control Board also proposed Monday that each water district be allowed to set its own conservation limits. That change will be considered May 18.</p><p><em>The Los Angeles Times</em> <a href="http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-water-conservation-20160509-story.html">explains </a>the shifting drought situation in recent years:</p><blockquote>
<p>As the drought intensified, Brown last year ordered a statewide 25% cut in urban water use, the first mandate of its kind in California history. To achieve that, the water board set individual targets for communities. Those with the highest per-capita use were ordered to reduce water consumption by as much as 36%.</p>

<p>Since then, the state’s overall urban use has dropped nearly 24% compared with 2013.</p>

<p>But water agencies up and down the state complained that the conservation targets didn’t take into account regional climate differences, previous conservation efforts or alternative supplies such as desalinated seawater.</p>
</blockquote><p>Still, the State Water Resources Control Board is planning on a much drier California in the next century. While a state law from 2009 already requires a 20 percent drop in per capita water use, officials are planning to push that number even higher.</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/1Q4L7fmDmC8" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>J. Weston Phippen</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/j-weston-phippen/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2016/05/RTX1M2HA/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Lucy Nicholson / Reuters</media:credit><media:description>A dry pipe drips water on Gless Ranch in Kern County, California.</media:description></media:content><title type="html">California's New Drought Rules</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/1Q4L7fmDmC8/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-10T11:24:00-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-10T11:25:30-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:50-482064</id><summary type="html">Governor Jerry Brown announced Monday that the state will keep some of emergency drought measures and relax others.</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/california-water/482064/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p><small><em>Updated on May 10 at 7:27 a.m. ET</em></small></p><p><strong>Clinton, Sanders do battle in West Virginia</strong>: The state votes today in its presidential primary. <a href="http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/latest_polls/">Polls show a tight race</a> between the two Democrats.</p><p><strong>The next president of the Philippines</strong>: Rodrigo Duterte is <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/05/philippiness-new-president/481950/?utm_source=feed">a tough-talking mayor</a> who transformed a southern city with a populist combination of controversial tactics and a deft touch. His main rival, Manuel Roxas, admitted defeat.</p><p><strong>Knife attack at German train station</strong>: <a href="http://www.dw.com/en/one-dead-after-stabbing-near-munich/a-19246270">One person has been killed</a> and three others wounded at the Grafing station near Munich. Police said the attacker, who was detained, was a 27-year-old German national. They have not ruled out a political motive for the attack. <strong>Update</strong>: Joachim Herrmann, the Bavarian interior minister, <a href="http://www.dw.com/en/one-dead-after-stabbing-near-munich/a-19246270">said</a> the suspect had a history of mental health and drug problems, and that the investigation so far, despite news reports, did not point to an Islamist motivation.</p><p><strong>Fort McMurray wildfire, cont’d</strong>: Rachel Notley, the Alberta premier, says about 90 percent of the city has survived the devastation that prompted the evacuation of more than 80,000 people. “It is going to be made safe,” <a href="http://edmontonjournal.com/news/local-news/premier-rachel-notley-to-tour-fort-mcmurray-wildfire-damage-today">she said</a>. “It is a home you will return to.”</p><p><strong>News from last night</strong> <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/?utm_source=feed#anchor-note-481989">here</a></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/JpYgNLAogYo" height="1" width="1" The…</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/what-were-following-this-morning/482028/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><figure><img alt="" height="585" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/sauvie/52476cdb5.jpg" width="630"></figure><p>I took this shot on Thursday during my flight back to D.C. from Portland, Oregon, where I was working remotely for a week while visiting family for my birthday—and I got the perfect gift of unseasonably sunny weather. This pastoral view along the Columbia River is just north of the city, and only until I read the GPS location on my iPhone photo did I realize I was just over Sauvie Island—the largest island along the Columbia and one of the largest river islands in the U.S. The northern half of Sauvie is a wildlife refuge and the southern half has scattered rural homes. It’s also a great place to run wild and eat wild strawberries, as my niece Freya can attest:</p><figure><img alt="" height="388" src="https://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/posts/2016/05/sauvie_strawberries-1/776d39c8b.jpg" width="630"></figure><p>For a wonderful little tribute to Portland, check out Rosa’s <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/orbital-view-city-of-roses/481215/?utm_source=feed">recent Orbital View on the “City of Roses</a>,” her hometown. (The note made my mother a little verklempt; she moved to the city a decade ago, married a Portland native and—after 50 years of the Air Force and then Army determining where she moved every few years—put down roots in Portland for good.) For an even better in-flight photo departing Portland, check out Rosa’s <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/all/2016/02/your-views-of-america-from-the-air/462432/?utm_source=feed#note-470601">crystal-clear view of Mt. Hood</a> just east of the city. If you’re a fellow Portlander and have an aerial photo above the city or surrounding area, <a href="mailto:hello@theatlantic.com">please send it our way</a>.</p><p dir="ltr"><em>(America by Air archive <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/category/america-by-air/?utm_source=feed">here</a>. Submission guidelines <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/all/2016/02/your-views-of-america-from-the-air/462432/?utm_source=feed#note-462156">here</a>.)</em></p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/woxEBdvdi8c" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Chris Bodenner</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/chris-bodenner/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/notes/2016/05/sauvie/lead_960.jpg" /><title type="html">Orbital View: Scenic Sauvie</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/woxEBdvdi8c/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-09T17:35:00-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-10T00:47:04-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:374-481992</id><summary type="html">I took this shot on Thursday during my flight back to D.C. from Portland, Oregon, where I was working…</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/notes/2016/05/orbital-view-scenic-sauvie-island/481992/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p>President Obama signed the National Bison Legacy Act on Monday, making the country’s official national mammal the American bison, also known colloquially as the buffalo.</p><p>The bison joins the ranks of the bald eagle, which serves as the country’s national bird. Congress approved the bipartisan bison legislation last month. The U.S. Department of the Interior <a href="https://www.doi.gov/blog/15-facts-about-our-national-mammal-american-bison">recalled</a> Monday the bison’s tumultuous experience once the Europeans arrived on the continent:</p><blockquote>
<p>In prehistoric times, millions of bison roamed North America—<a href="http://www.nature.nps.gov/biology/bisonbellow/january7.cfm">from the forests of Alaska and the grasslands of Mexico to Nevada’s Great Basin and the eastern Appalachian Mountains</a>. But by the late 1800s, there were only a few hundred bison left in the United States after European settlers pushed west, reducing the animal’s habitat and hunting the bison to near extinction. Had it not been for a few private individuals working with tribes, states and the Interior Department, the bison would be extinct today.</p>
</blockquote><p>Native Americans had long traveled beside the herds, using their meat, hide, and horns to survive. When European and American trappers started to travel west, they killed the animal for its fur. Bison hunting intensified in the 1860s, as railroads tied east to west and allowed people to reach once-desolate lands more easily. It brought people like William Cody, a U.S. Cavalry scout who earned the nickname “Buffalo Bill” for killing 5,000 bison in just 18 months. At one point, the U.S. military killed any bison it encountered, assuming that if the animals were eradicated, so too would be the Native Americans.</p><p>Today, there are 500,000 bison in the U.S., and about 10,000 of those live on public land and are overseen by the Department of the Interior. They roam in 17 herds in 12 states. Yellowstone National Park, the only place in the country where bison have lived continually, is home to the largest herd.</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/pBXhs7zqtjs" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>J. Weston Phippen</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/j-weston-phippen/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2016/05/AP_674994538067/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>Amber Hunt / AP</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">Bald Eagle, Meet the American Bison</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/pBXhs7zqtjs/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-09T17:20:00-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-09T17:42:49-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:50-481947</id><summary type="html">President Obama has signed legislation making the bison the national mammal of the United States.</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/american-bison/481947/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p>A Florida judge has ruled the state’s death-penalty statue is unconstitutional, two months after the law was amended in accordance with a U.S. Supreme Court decision this year that found it violated the<strong> </strong>Constitution.</p><p>In March, Florida introduced a new capital-sentencing system in response to a Supreme Court decision in January that <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/01/florida-death-penalty/423774/?utm_source=feed">determined</a> the current rules violated the Sixth Amendment’s guarantee of a jury trial. In most states, a jury must make a unanimous decision to determine whether a death sentence is appropriate for an individual who is found guilty of a capital offense. In Florida, the jury played an advisory role, able only to offer a recommended sentence. The actual sentence would come from the judge in the case, who would independently weigh the evidence.</p><p>Florida’s new law requires that at least 10 of 12 jury members agree on a death sentence. On Monday, a circuit court judge in Miami-Dade, Milton Hirsch, said in a ruling that the statute still misses the mark, and urged that unanimity be required to sentence someone to die:</p><blockquote>
<p>We ask only that such decisions reflect the will of the many rather than the will of the few. But for the ultimate decisions made within the judicial branch of government—guilty or not guilty, life or death—majority rule is insufficient. We do ask, indeed we insist, that the decision of capital juries be, in some sense, perfect; for they are, in some sense, final. We ask, indeed we insist, that they reflect the will of all rather than the will of the few or even of the many. Only when the jury agrees to its verdict unanimously can we demand that society accept the verdict unanimously.</p>
</blockquote><p><a href="http://www.deathpenaltyinfo.org/files/pdf/20160509092842101.pdf">In his ruling</a>, Hirsch cited Andrew Cohen’s April 2014 article in <em>The Atlantic </em>on Louisiana’s <a href="http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2014/04/Louisiana/360726/?utm_source=feed">non-unanimous jury verdicts</a> in murder trials. He issued the ruling in the case of Karon Gaiter, who is awaiting trial for first-degree murder, <a href="http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/florida-judge-death-penalty-law-unconstitutional-38989386">according to the AP</a>.</p><p>Except for Alabama and Delaware, all 33 states that have the death penalty <a href="http://www.eji.org/deathpenalty/override">require a unanimous jury verdict</a> to impose the death sentence. In those two states, judges can override juries’ recommendations against a death sentence.</p><img src="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~4/NtikoUpl8C8" height="1" width="1" alt=""/></content><author><name>Marina Koren</name><uri>http://www.theatlantic.com/author/marina-koren/</uri></author><media:content url="http://cdn.theatlantic.com/assets/media/img/mt/2016/05/AP_321284892763/lead_960.jpg"><media:credit>David Goldman / Reuters</media:credit></media:content><title type="html">The Legal Controversy Over Florida's Death Penalty</title><link href="http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/AtlanticNational/~3/NtikoUpl8C8/" rel="alternate" /><published>2016-05-09T16:32:41-04:00</published><updated>2016-05-09T16:33:22-04:00</updated><id>tag:theatlantic.com,2016:50-481902</id><summary type="html">A circuit-court judge has ruled that newly introduced sentencing laws are unconstitutional.</summary><feedburner:origLink>http://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2016/05/florida-death-penalty/481902/</feedburner:origLink></entry><entry><content type="html"><p>Bordered by the ocean to the west and Golden Gate Park to the north, the Sunset District is home to about 85,000 people:</p><blockquote class="instagram-media" data-instgrm-version="6" style=" background:#FFF; border:0; border-radius:3px; box-shadow:0 0 1px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.5),0 1px 10px 0 rgba(0,0,0,0.15); margin: 1px; max-width:658px; padding:0; width:99.375%; width:-webkit-calc(100% - 2px); width:calc(100% - 2px);">
<div style="padding:8px;">
<div style=" background:#F8F8F8; line-height:0; margin-top:40px; padding:50.0% 0; text-align:center; width:100%;">
<div style=" background:url(data:image/png;base64,); display:block; height:44px; margin:0 auto -44px; position:relative; top:-22px; width:44px;"></div>
</div>

<p style=" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px; margin-bottom:0; margin-top:8px; overflow:hidden; padding:8px 0 7px; text-align:center; text-overflow:ellipsis; white-space:nowrap;"><a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/BFJAoNaLEoS/" style=" color:#c9c8cd; font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; font-style:normal; font-weight:normal; line-height:17px; text-decoration:none;" target="_blank">A photo posted by Anthony Quigley 📸 (@anthonyquigley)</a> on <time datetime="2016-05-08T09:11:52+00:00" style=" font-family:Arial,sans-serif; font-size:14px; line-height:17px;">May 8, 2016 at 2:11am PDT</time></p>
</div>
</blockquote><script async defer src="//platform.instagram.com/en_US/embeds.js"></script><p><span style="line-height: 1.66667;">Quigley quotes from a </span><a href="http://summitsf.com/neighborhoods/outer-sunset" style="line-height: 1.66667;">real-estate listing</a><span style="line-height: 1.66667;">:</span></p><blockquote>
<p>[The Sunset] is one of San Francisco’s most family-friendly neighborhoods, with sprawling blocks of quaint single-family abodes. The restaurants and bars at western base of Twin Peaks provide lattes to baby-clad mothers while the surfing community holes up on the cool, fog-laden beachfront huts lining the Great American Highway.</p>
